title: Lesson 1: Greetings and Basic Introductions
description: Learn basic German greetings and how to introduce yourself, including asking about well-being.
objectives: Greet someone in German using different greetings
Introduce yourself by stating your name, origin, and profession
Ask someone their name and how they are, and respond appropriately
Understand the difference between formal and informal greetings and apply them correctly
grammar: Formal vs. Informal 'you' (Sie vs. du)
Subject pronouns (Ich, Sie, du)
Verb 'heißen' (to be called/named) conjugation (ich heiße, du heißt, Sie heißen)
Verb 'sein' (to be) conjugation (ich bin, Sie sind)
Verb 'wohnen' (to live) conjugation (ich wohne)
Verb 'kommen' (to come) conjugation (ich komme, Sie kommen)
Basic question formation (inversion with 'wie geht es', 'woher kommen Sie', etc.)
Prepositions 'aus' (from) and 'in' (in)

title: Lesson 2: Saying Goodbye and Basic Courtesy and Expressing Feelings
description: Learn different ways to say goodbye, basic phrases of courtesy, and how to express feelings.
objectives: Say goodbye in German using various expressions
Say 'please' and 'thank you' in formal and informal contexts
Ask how someone is doing and respond appropriately
Express basic feelings (happy, sad, tired)
Use 'gern' and 'nicht gern' to express liking and disliking
phrases: Es geht mir nicht so gut.
grammar: Formal vs. informal 'you' revisited (Sie vs. du) in context
Using 'es geht mir' (It goes to me) structure
Adverbs of degree (sehr, so, nicht)
Politeness phrases and their use
Reflexive verbs (sich fühlen – introduced implicitly)
Using 'gern' and 'nicht gern' with verbs to express preferences
Adjectives to describe feelings (traurig, müde)

title: Lesson 3: Numbers 1-20 and Basic Calculations
description: Learn to count from one to twenty in German and perform simple calculations.
objectives: Count from 1 to 20 in German
Understand and respond to questions asking 'How many?'
Perform simple addition and subtraction in German
Practice pronunciation of German numbers and mathematical terms
grammar: Cardinal numbers 1-20
Introduced verb 'haben' (to have) - first person singular and plural (ich habe, wir haben)
Question formation with 'Wie viele?'
Basic math equation structure (number + operator + number + 'ist' + result)

title: Lesson 4: Colors and Describing Objects
description: Learn the names of basic colors in German and how to describe objects using adjectives.
objectives: Name common colors in German
Ask what color something is
Describe the color of an object
Use adjectives correctly with nouns, including size and shape adjectives
Begin to understand basic adjective agreement
grammar: Basic sentence structure: Subject + Verb + Object (Color as an adjective)
Introduction to definite articles (der, die, das)
Introduction to indefinite articles (ein, eine)
Adjective agreement (basic concept introduced – adjective endings change slightly depending on the article)
Common adjectives for describing objects (size, shape, appearance)

title: Lesson 5: The Family and Possessions
description: Learn the names for family members in German and how to talk about possessions.
objectives: Name basic family members in German
Talk about your family and describe them
Ask about someone else's family and their possessions
Use possessive pronouns and the verb 'haben' effectively
grammar: Possessive pronouns (mein/meine, dein/deine) – reinforcement of gendered nouns
Plural form of nouns (introduced contextually and practiced)
Verb 'haben' (to have) conjugation (ich habe, du hast)
Basic questions with 'Hast du?' and 'Was hast du?'
Adjectives to describe people (alt, jung, nett, freundlich)

title: Lesson 6: Food, Drink, and Ordering in a Café
description: Learn to name common foods and drinks in German, and practice ordering in a café scenario.
objectives: Name common foods and drinks
Say what you like to eat and drink
Ask what someone else likes
Use 'gern' with verbs to express liking
Order food and drinks in a simulated café setting
grammar: Verb 'mögen' (to like) conjugation (ich mag, du magst) with food
Verb 'essen' (to eat) and 'trinken' (to drink) - infinitive form introduced
Indefinite articles (kein/keine) in negative statements – further practice
Using 'gern' to express preference – reinforced and expanded usage
Introduced 'ich möchte' (I would like) for ordering
Asking questions in a café context (Was möchten Sie?)

title: Lesson 7: Days of the Week, Months, and Seasons
description: Learn the days of the week, months, and seasons in German.
objectives: Name the days of the week in German
Say what day it is
Ask what day it is
Use prepositions of time (am)
Name the months and seasons in German
vocabulary: Am (On – contracted with 'dem' for days of the week)
grammar: Days of the week (capitalization)
Basic sentence structure with 'ist'
Preposition 'am' (on) with days of the week – reinforced
Question formation with 'Welcher Tag?'
Months and seasons (capitalization)
Preposition 'im' (in the – contracted with 'dem' for seasons) – introduced

title: Lesson 8: Telling Time (O'Clock and Half Past)
description: Learn to tell time in German using o'clock and half past.
objectives: Tell time to the hour and half past in German
Ask what time it is
Answer the question 'What time is it?'
Understand the structure 'Es ist ... Uhr' and 'Es ist halb ...'
vocabulary: Viertel (Quarter) - introduced implicitly in later lessons
grammar: Using 'Es ist' to tell time
Numbers 1-12 (review) in the context of time
Clock time structure (Es ist [number] Uhr)
Introducing 'Es ist halb [next hour]' to express half past
Mention concept of 'Viertel' (quarter) for later use

title: Lesson 9: Hobbies and Activities and Frequency
description: Learn how to talk about hobbies and activities in German and how often you do them.
objectives: Name common hobbies and activities
Say what you like to do and how often
Ask what someone else likes to do and how often
Use adverbs of frequency
grammar: Verb 'spielen' and other action verbs (infinitive form)
Adverb 'gern' (gladly/like to) with verbs - reinforcement
Verb conjugation (ich spiele, du spielst - simple present tense reinforcement)
Basic question formation (Was machst du?)
Adverbs of frequency (oft, manchmal, nie, immer)
Using 'jeden Tag' and 'am Wochenende' to indicate frequency

title: Lesson 10: Where do you live? Describing your Home
description: Learn to ask and answer questions about where someone lives and describe your home.
objectives: Ask where someone lives
Answer where you live
Name some common places
Use prepositions of location (in)
Describe your home and its features
phrases: Ich wohne in einer Stadt/einem Dorf.
Es gibt eine Küche und ein Bad.
grammar: Verb 'wohnen' (to live) conjugation (ich wohne, du wohnst)
Preposition 'in' (in) with place names – reinforced
Concept of dative case (in einer Stadt/einem Dorf) – implicit recognition
Question formation with 'Wo?'
Using 'haben' to describe possessions
Introducing 'es gibt' (there is/are) to describe features of a home
Adjectives to describe a home (klein, groß, modern, alt, hell, dunkel)
